[[Visual novel]] | platforms = Windows, DVD, PS2, PSP | released = {{vgrelease|JP|April 28, 2005}}{{vgrelease|JP|October 8, 2010 (''HQ'')}}{{vgrelease|NA|June 27, 2012 (''HQ'')}} }} {{Infobox animanga/Print | type = manga | author = 0verflow | illustrator = Homare Sakazuki | publisher = [[Kadokawa Shoten]] | demographic = ''[[Seinen manga|Seinen]]'' | magazine = [[Comp Ace]] | first = May 26, 2006 | last = September 26, 2007 | volumes = 2 | volume_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Audio | title = Radio School Days | director = | producer = | writer = | music = | studio = TNK | station = Lantis Net Radio | first = June 26, 2007 | last = March 28, 2008 | episodes = 39 | episode_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Video | type = tv series | director = Keitaro Motonaga | producer = Katsumi Koike
Makoto Ito
Masanori Goto | writer = [[Makoto Uezu]] | music = Kaoru Okubo | studio = [[TNK (company)|TNK]] | licensee = {{English anime licensee|NA=[[Discotek Media]]}} | network = [[TV Kanagawa]], [[Chiba TV]], [[TV Aichi]], [[TV Osaka]], [[TV Saitama]], [[AT-X (company)|AT-X]] | first = July 3, 2007 | last = September 27, 2007 | episodes = 12 | episode_list = List of School Days episodes }} {{Infobox animanga/Video | type = ova | title = Valentine Days | director = Keitaro Motonaga | producer = | writer = Makoto Uezu | music = Kaoru Okubo | studio = TNK | released = January 17, 2008 | runtime = 19 minutes }} {{Infobox animanga/Video | type = ova | title = Magical Heart Kokoro-chan | director = Keitaro Motonaga | producer = | writer = Makoto Uezu | music = Kaoru Okubo | studio = TNK | licensee = {{English anime licensee|NA=[[Discotek Media]]}} | released = March 26, 2008 | runtime = 25 minutes }} {{Infobox animanga/Footer}} {{nihongo|'''''School Days'''''|スクールデイズ|Sukūru Deizu|}} is a Japanese [[visual novel]] developed by [[0verflow]], released on April 28, 2005 for [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] as an [[Eroge|adult game]]. It was later [[Porting|ported]] as a [[DVD game]] and for the [[PlayStation 2]] (PS2) and [[PlayStation Portable]] (PSP). The story, a dramatic [[slice-of-life]], follows Makoto Ito, a high school student who becomes the ambivalent love interest of several girls during his second term, and the effects this has on himself and his relationships with other characters. Though the game requires little interaction from users, ''School Days'' engages the player through a plot that they are given opportunities to change the course of during play. The game concludes with an ending specific to the outcome of the story, some of which became notorious for their [[graphic violence]]. 0verflow announced work on ''School Days'' in October 2004 and marketed it through public venues that showcased the game's innovative use of [[anime]]-like cinematics and voice. The game ranked as the best-selling visual novel in Japan for the time of its release, continuing to chart in the national top 50 for nearly five months afterward. 0verflow would then go on to produce [[#Sequels|multiple sequels]] including a [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] of the original story called ''[[Summer Days]]'', and a [[Sequel#Parallel|parallel]] story called ''[[Cross Days]]''. Another spin-off, ''[[Island Days]]'', has been developed by Klon for the [[Nintendo 3DS]]. ''School Days'' was remastered as ''School Days HQ'' on October 8, 2010 and localized in North America on June 27, 2012. The original game was officially discontinued April 21, 2011. Following the game's release, ''School Days'' made several transitions into other media. The original story was adapted into a [[manga]] and serialized in the [[Kadokawa Shoten]] magazine ''[[Comp Ace]]''; it was later published into two volumes. [[Comic anthology|Comic anthologies]], [[light novel]]s and [[art book]]s were also published, as were [[audio drama]]s and several albums of music. An animated television series, two [[direct-to-video]] ([[OVA]]) single releases, and a [[concert film]] were also produced, the first of which became a precursor for an [[internet meme]] when its finale was pulled from broadcast. ==Gameplay== [[File:Schooldayshqcscreen.jpg|thumb|left|Example of a selection screen from the North American release of ''School Days HQ''. Here, Kotonoha has asked Makoto a question. Players may choose one of the available options or none at all.]] As a visual novel, ''School Days'' contains extremely minimal gameplay. The game's core onscreen presentation is composed of scenes that are viewed from a mostly third-person perspective. At predetermined intervals, the game pauses, and players are presented with one to two responses or actions relevant to the scene in progress to make, or not make, on behalf of characters. Each selection branches the game's progress up to that point in an alternate direction, while also causing the player's love toward a character to blossom, plateau, or diminish,{{cite web|url=http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scdspec.html|title=School Days: Spec|publisher=[[0verflow]]|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-02|language=Japanese}} thus providing for a nonlinear storytelling experience. Being an erotic title, relationships between characters may become sexual; scenes of this kind depict a varying combination of [[French kissing]], masturbation, oral sex, intercourse, and nudity (both female and male) or a combination thereof. Genitalia are [[pixelization|pixelated]] in the original Japanese releases, but the Western release of ''School Days HQ'' is uncensored.{{cite web|url=http://www.getchu.com/soft.phtml?id=196481&gc=gc|title=Getchu.com: School Days|publisher=Getchu.com|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese}} Sex scenes are omitted from the PlayStation 2 and PlayStation Portable ports of the game. Each route the game takes invariably concludes with an ending specific to the choices made up to that point. Depending on these choices, the outcome of the story will either be good or bad. ''School Days'' became popularly known for its bad endings,{{cite web|url=http://www.japanator.com/a-new-version-of-school-days-a-new-way-to-die-horribly-16909.phtml|title=A new version of School Days, a new way to die horribly |publisher=Japanator|date=2010-10-15|author=Pedro Cortes|accessdate=2012-01-15}} which depict the deaths of characters. In one ending titled "The Bloody Conclusion", a character's neck is slit open with a [[dōzuki]], causing her to collapse and die in a fountain of blood to the manic laughter of her assailant.{{cite video game|title=School Days|developer=[[0verflow]]|publisher=Stack|date=2005-04-28|platform=[[Microsoft Windows|Windows]]|version=|scene={{nihongo|''Ryuuketsu no Ketsuron''|流血の結論||extra2="The Bloody Conclusion"}}|language=Japanese}} In another called "Eternally", a character commits suicide leaning over and falling off the roof of a school, landing headfirst on a sidewalk to the horror of other characters.{{cite video game|title=School Days|developer=[[0verflow]]|publisher=Stack|date=2005-04-28|platform=[[Microsoft Windows|Windows]]|version=|scene={{nihongo|''Eienni''|永遠に||extra2="Eternally"}}|language=Japanese}} The game's good endings, by contrast, depict the well-being of characters and their relationships. In the ending "Christmas Eve", a couple share an embrace in a hotel room as snow falls around a surrounding cityscape.{{cite video game|title=School Days|developer=[[0verflow]]|publisher=Stack|date=2005-04-28|platform=[[Microsoft Windows|Windows]]|version=|scene={{nihongo|''Kurisumasu Ibu''|クリスマスイブ||extra2="Christmas Eve"}}|language=Japanese}} In another titled "Two Lovers", a pair of characters agree to have a [[Polyamory|polyamorous]] relationship with the male lead instead of rivaling with each other.{{cite video game|title=School Days|developer=[[0verflow]]|publisher=Stack|date=2005-04-28|platform=[[Microsoft Windows|Windows]]|version=|scene={{nihongo|''Futari no Koibito''|二人の恋人||extra2="Two Lovers"}}|language=Japanese}} Because of the numerous [[alternate ending]]s that can be achieved, players who wish to watch additional endings and sex scenes will have to play through the game more than once.{{cite web|url=http://visual-novels.net/vn/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=259&Itemid=47|title=What are visual novels?|publisher=Visual-novels.net|accessdate=2012-01-14}} Unlike traditional visual novels that consist of static characters with subtitled dialogue, ''School Days'' is unusual in that it incorporates motion and voice, making it reminiscent of an animated series. Cinematics naturally play on their own, and players are afforded the ability to pause, fast-forward, and even skip those they've seen before. Male and female voices can be muted, subtitles can be turned on or off and the game can be played from a window or fullscreen ratio. Progress can be saved at any time in up to 100 slots and loaded from either the main menu or during play. ==Plot== {{See also|List of School Days characters}} ''School Days'' focuses on the life of Makoto Ito, a first-year high school student{{cite web|url=http://schooldayshq.0verflow.com/chara_makoto.html|title=School Days HQ: Makoto It|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-07|language=Japanese}} living with his divorced and [[Unseen character|unseen]] mother in the fictional city of Haramihama. During his second term, he becomes infatuated with Kotonoha Katsura, a soft-spoken schoolmate who shares train rides with him to and from campus. When his homeroom seating plan is rearranged, he becomes acquaintances with Sekai Saionji, an upbeat girl who takes a special interest in his newfound crush, befriending the two and providing them the grounds to meet.{{cite web|url=http://schooldayshq.0verflow.com/chara_sekai.html|title=School Days HQ: Sekai Saionji|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-07|language=Japanese}} In spite of her triumphant efforts however, Sekai becomes jealous of the new couple, having developed feelings for Makoto herself. ==Development== ''School Days'' was 0verflow's tenth game to develop.{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/html/products/index.html|title=0verflow game list|publisher=0verflow|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, Japan|accessdate=2012-01-09|language=Japanese}} News of ''School Days'' first surfaced on October 5, 2004 when 0verflow posted a link to the game's then-live website and development log on their official site.{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/html/top.html|title=0verflow blog: Public School Days Special Page|publisher=[[0verflow]]|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-07|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041009164803/http://www.0verflow.com/html/|archivedate=2004-10-09 }} In the blog, 0verflow revealed that ''School Days'' had been in pre-production for roughly two years and would be a fully animated game. Updates on the development of the game were scheduled for Tuesdays and Fridays, and the company encouraged fans to attend Dream Party 2004, an upcoming anime convention at [[Tokyo Big Sight]] in [[Ariake, Tokyo|Ariake]], on October 11, where it would make its first public showcase of the game and characters.{{cite web|url=http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scdays_0410.html|title=Development blog: October 2004|publisher=[[0verflow]]|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-08|language=Japanese}} A follow-up of the venue was made on October 15. Toward the end of the month on October 26, 0verflow posted that new information about ''School Days'' would be circulated in the November issue of ''Tech Gian'', an adult magazine published by [[Enterbrain]].{{cite web|url=http://www.techgian.jp/official/tg201202/|title=Tech Gian official website|publisher=[[Enterbrain]]|location=Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-08|language=Japanese}} Promotion for the game began shortly after. In a November 6 development post, 0verflow announced that it was planning a public screening of new game material, but was experiencing difficulty acquiring space for it. The company had initially chosen to have the venue in [[Akihabara]] but was unable to find a retailer willing to host it, prompting a visit to [[Osaka]] the following week.{{cite web|url=http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scdays_0411.html|title=Development blog: November 2004|publisher=[[0verflow]]|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-08|language=Japanese}} News that the game would contain music by artists such as [[Minami Kuribayashi]], [[Haruko Momoi]], [[Yozuca|Yozuca*]] and [[YURIA]] was posted on November 30, along with a release date change to February 25, 2005. On December 28, 2004,{{cite web|url=http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scdays_0412.html|title=Development blog: December 2004|publisher=0verflow|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, Japan|accessdate=2012-01-08|language=Japanese}} 0verflow released a public trial of ''School Days'' and announced that the company would be attending [[Comiket]] 67 at Tokyo Big Sight from December 29 to 30, handing out [[phonecard]]s to the first 50 visitors to their booth.{{cite web|url=http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scdevent.html|title=Event information: Comiket 67|publisher=[[0verflow]]|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-07|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041230234007/http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scdevent.html|archivedate=2004-12-30}} Two months later, on February 2, 2005, the company announced that the game had been postponed again to April 28.{{cite web|url=http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scdays_0502.html|title=Development blog: February 2005|publisher=0verflow|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, Japan|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese}} From April 5 to April 8, 0verflow concluded their development log with comments from [[Soyogi Tōno]], Kaname Yuzuki, Tatsuya Hirai, [[Yuki Matsunaga]], Hikaru Isshiki and Hana Yamamoto, the respective voices of Kotonoha, Sekai, Makoto, Otome, Hikari and Setsuna.{{cite web|url=http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scdays.html|title=Development blog: April 2004|publisher=0verflow|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, Japan|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese}} To address bugs that were later found in the game, 0verflow released a patch to bring ''School Days'' to a stable build of 1.11.{{cite web|url=http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scddownload.html|title=School Days downloads|publisher=[[0verflow]]|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese}} On June 26, 2007, 0verflow and Lantis-net radio began to air an internet radio drama called "Radio School Days".{{cite web|url=http://0verflow.com/html/diary/2007/20070626_diary.html|title=Radio School Days begins today!|publisher=[[0verflow]]|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041009164803/http://0verflow.com/html/diary/2007/20070626_diary.html|archivedate=2004-10-09 }} Broadcasts finished up March 28, 2008 with 39 episodes aired.{{cite web|url=http://lantis-net.com/schooldays/index.html|title=Radio School Days: 39th final broadcast|publisher=[[Lantis (company)|Lantis]]|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080902040854/http://lantis-net.com/schooldays/index.html|archivedate=2008-09-02 }} On April 21, 2011,{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/web/|title=Overflow: Information|publisher=[[0verflow]]|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-07|language=Japanese}} 0verflow announced via their blog that support for ''School Days'' was being discontinued.{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/web/schooldayslotup|title=School Days discontinued|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, Japan|publisher=0verflow|accessdate=2012-01-07|language=Japanese}} ===Release history=== ''School Days'' was [[Porting|ported]] to three other platforms. The first of these was by AiCherry, an [[interactive movie]] developer, who announced on August 20, 2007 that it had picked up the game for development,{{cite web|url=http://www.aicherry.com/mainpage.html|title=Update History: Latest title: School Days|publisher=AiCherry|accessdate=2012-01-02|language=Japanese|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070819094114/http://www.aicherry.com/mainpage.html|archivedate=2007-08-19 }} releasing it as a four disc [[DVD game]] on September 28.{{cite web|url=http://www.aicherry.com/aicherry/AICDV-0143/AICDV-0143.html|title=School Days DVD Players Game|publisher=AiCherry|accessdate=2012-01-10|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080330030433/http://www.aicherry.com/aicherry/AICDV-0143/AICDV-0143.html|archivedate=2008-03-30}} That same year, on August 31,{{cite web|url=http://www.interchannel.co.jp/|title=Interchannel Holon Inc.|publisher=[[Interchannel]]|accessdate=2012-01-10|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010125850/http://www.interchannel.co.jp/|archivedate=2007-10-10|deadurl=yes|df=}} [[Interchannel]] posted a link on their blog to the official website of ''School Days L×H'', a [[PlayStation 2]] (PS2) port in development by Guyzware,{{cite web|url=http://www.guyzware.jp/works/|title=School Days L×H at Guyzware|location=Tokyo, Japan|publisher=Guyzware|accessdate=2012-06-11|language=Japanese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Cy36iJS7?url=http://www.guyzware.jp/works/|archivedate=2012-12-17|df=}} that would be edited of explicit sexual content. The game was released on January 17, 2008{{cite web|url=http://www.interchannel.jp/game/SDLH/index.html|title=School Days L × H on sale today!|publisher=[[Interchannel]]|accessdate=2012-01-11|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080120195524/http://www.interchannel.jp/game/SDLH/index.html|archivedate=2008-01-20}} and assessed by the [[Computer Entertainment Rating Organization]] (CERO), Japan's primary [[video game content rating system]], receiving a 15-years-or-older "C" rating for sexual themes and profanity.{{cite web|url=http://www.cero.gr.jp/search/search.cgi?chkRT=C&chkPF=PS2&name=%A5%B9%A5%AF%A1%BC%A5%EB%A5%C7%A5%A4%A5%BA&txtCP=&sort=4|title=School Days L×H ratings|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[Computer Entertainment Rating Organization|CERO]]|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese}} The third and final port was developed by PalaceGame for the [[PlayStation Portable]] (PSP). After postponing the game on May 11, it was released as four [[Universal Media Disc|UMD]]s on June 30, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.palacegame.cc/detail.php?id=0009|title=「SchoolDays」UMD-PG Edition|publisher=PalaceGame|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese}} 0verflow opened what would become the homepage for ''School Days HQ'' on May 21, 2010, a remastering of the original game initially scheduled for release in August.{{cite web|url=http://schooldayshq.0verflow.com/|title=School Days HQ: Coming soon|publisher=[[0verflow]]|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-07|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100524144906/http://schooldayshq.0verflow.com/|archivedate=2010-05-24}} The site was finished June 3, and on July 16, the game was postponed to September 24. A trial was publicly released for download on August 7, and from August 20 to September 28, 0verflow promoted the game.{{cite web|url=http://schooldayshq.0verflow.com/|title=School Days HQ: What's New|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese}} Customers who had purchased the original ''School Days'' would be given the opportunity to upgrade to ''HQ'' for a fee until October 11, by either mailing in their game disc or visiting stores in Akihabara, Osaka or Nagoya.{{cite web|url=http://schooldayshq.0verflow.com/topics_upgrade.html|title=School Days HQ upgrade campaign information|publisher=[[0verflow]]|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese}} Distributors offered collectable phonecards for reservations,{{cite web|url=http://schooldayshq.0verflow.com/topics_tenpo_tokuten.html|title=Store reservation phonecards|publisher=[[0verflow]]|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese}} and after a second date change on September 10, the game was released October 8. On March 3, 2011, 0verflow acknowledged [[Sekai Project]], an unofficial [[Fan translation (video gaming)|fan translation]] group, who had reportedly begun [[Language localisation|localizing]] ''School Days'' in April 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.sekaiproject.net/news/200703/|title=Welcome to the Sekai Project website|publisher=Sekai Project|accessdate=2012-01-03|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070524094108/http://www.sekaiproject.net/news/200703/|archivedate=2007-05-24}} Partnering with American distributor [[JAST USA]], ''School Days HQ'', uncensored in English, was announced for a North American release on March 11, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.jastusa.com/school-days-is-coming-in-english|title=School Days is coming in English!|publisher=JAST USA|date=2011-03-01|accessdate=2012-01-03}} Development instead continued into 2012, and on May 18, JAST announced that the company had begun taking pre-orders for the Collector's Edition, a bundled release of the game packaged with a keychain and mousepad.{{cite web|url=http://jastusa.com/blog/2012/05/18/school-days-hq-collectors-edition-now-available-for-preorder/|title=School Days HQ Collector’s Edition Now Available For Preorder|publisher=JAST USA|date=2012-05-18|accessdate=2012-05-18}} The company announced weeks later on June 1 that ''School Days HQ'' had [[Golden master|gone gold]].{{cite web|url=http://jastusa.com/blog/2012/06/01/school-days-hq-goes-golden-master/|title=School Days HQ Goes Golden Master|publisher=JAST USA|date=2012-06-01|accessdate=2012-06-05}} Following news on June 26 that the company would exhibit the game at [[Anime Expo]] 2012,{{cite web|url=http://jastusa.com/blog/2012/06/26/jast-panel-at-anime-expo-2012/|title=JAST Panel at Anime Expo 2012|publisher=JAST USA|date=2012-06-26|accessdate=2012-06-27}} JAST made an update to the June 1 announcement that ''School Days HQ'' had begun shipping. The downloadable version of the game was later released on August 6.{{cite web|url=http://jastusa.com/blog/2012/08/06/school-days-hq-available-for-download/|title=School Days HQ Available for Download|publisher=JAST USA|date=2012-08-06|accessdate=2012-10-09}} ==Sales== In a national sales ranking of [[bishōjo game]]s in ''PCNEWS'', a now-defunct Japanese [[online magazine]], ''School Days'' premiered as the number one game sold for the second half of April 2005,{{cite web|url=http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank170.html|title=TOP50　PC NEWS No.170（4/16〜4/30）|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=Peaks, Inc.|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051227194657/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank170.html|archivedate=2005-12-27}} the second and seventeenth for the first and second halves of May,{{cite web|url=http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank171.html|title=TOP50　PC NEWS No.171（5/01〜5/15）|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=Peaks, Inc.|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051218034042/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank171.html|archivedate=2005-12-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank172.html|title=TOP50　PC NEWS No.172（5/16〜5/31）|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=Peaks, Inc.|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051218032756/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank172.html|archivedate=2005-12-18}} the fifth and twenty-sixth for the first and second halves of June,{{cite web|url=http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank173.html|title=TOP50　PC NEWS No.173（6/01〜6/15）|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=Peaks, Inc.|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051218042907/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank173.html|archivedate=2005-12-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank174.html|title=TOP50　PC NEWS No.174（6/16〜6/30）|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=Peaks, Inc.|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051218032042/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank174.html|archivedate=2005-12-18}} and twenty-seventh for the first half of July.{{cite web|url=http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank175.html|title=TOP50　PC NEWS No.175（7/01〜7/15）|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=Peaks, Inc.|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051218044929/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank175.html|archivedate=2005-12-18}} The ''School Days'' renewal edition, released a week after the previous ranking, continued to chart on behalf of the game; it ranked as the thirty-third most sold game for the second half of July,{{cite web|url=http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank176.html|title=TOP50　PC NEWS No.176（7/16〜7/31）|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=Peaks, Inc.|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051218044929/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank176.html|archivedate=2005-12-18}} before ending as the thirty-fifth and forty-ninth for the first and second halves of August.{{cite web|url=http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank177.html|title=TOP50　PC NEWS No.177（8/1〜8/15）|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=Peaks, Inc.|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051222033753/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank177.html|archivedate=2005-12-22}}{{cite web|url=http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank178.html|title=TOP50　PC NEWS No.178（8/16〜8/31）|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=Peaks, Inc.|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051222051119/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank178.html|archivedate=2005-12-22}} Getchu.com, a major distributor of visual novels and domestic anime products, recorded similar sales. ''School Days'' for Windows premiered as the number one game sold for the month of its release,{{cite web|url=http://www.getchu.com/pc/salesranking200504.html|title=April 2005 sales rankings!|publisher=Getchu.com|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese}} and seventh most for May,{{cite web|url=http://www.getchu.com/pc/salesranking200505.html|title=June 2005 sales rankings!|publisher=Getchu.com|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese}} ranking as the number one game sold for the first half of 2005{{cite web|url=http://www.getchu.com/pc/2005-1salesranking.html|title=First half of 2005 sales rankings!|publisher=Getchu.com|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese}} and ninth for the year.{{cite web|url=http://www.getchu.com/pc/salesranking2005.html|title=2005 sales rankings!|publisher=Getchu.com|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese}} The following year, the ''School Days'' renewal edition charted as the twentieth most sold game for July 2007,{{cite web|url=http://www.getchu.com/pc/salesranking200707.html|title=July 2007 sales rankings!|publisher=Getchu.com|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese}} dropping to thirtieth from August to October.{{cite web|url=http://www.getchu.com/pc/salesranking200708.html|title=August 2007 sales rankings!|publisher=Getchu.com|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese}}{{cite web|url=http://www.getchu.com/pc/salesranking200709.html|title=September 2007 sales rankings!|publisher=Getchu.com|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese}}{{cite web|url=http://www.getchu.com/pc/salesranking200710.html|title=October 2007 sales rankings!|publisher=Getchu.com|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese}} ''School Days HQ'' ranked as the sixth most sold game for October 2010{{cite web|url=http://www.getchu.com/pc/salesranking201010.html|title=October 2010 sales rankings!|publisher=Getchu.com|accessdate=2012-01-03|language=Japanese}} but failed to chart thereafter. According to ''[[Gamasutra]]'', a video gaming news site, ''School Days L×H'' ranked as the number one PlayStation 2 game sold for January 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=16979|title=Saling The World: U.S. Wii Owners Shift Attention to Budget Releases |publisher=[[Gamasutra]]|author=Danny Cowan|date=2008-01-18|accessdate=2012-01-19}} ==Media== ===Related visual novels=== 0verflow developed several visual novels related to ''School Days'', sharing the same universe. Prior to the development of ''School Days'', 0verflow developed the ''Radish Vacation'' visual novel series. The first is ''Snow Radish Vacation'' released on December 28, 2001, followed by ''Summer Radish Vacation'' on April 1, 2003 and finally ''Summer Radish Vacation 2'' on August 13, 2004.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} A [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] titled ''[[Summer Days]]'', was released on June 23, 2006, retelling the original game during summer vacation and from the perspective of Setsuna Kiyoura.{{cite web|url=http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scfdfaq.html|title=Summer Days: FAQ|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, Japan|publisher=0verflow|accessdate=2012-12-26|language=Japanese}} Unlike its predecessor, however, ''Summer Days'' was almost universally panned for its heavily bugged state,{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/html/topics/060628_apology.html|title= Apology for Summer Days|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, Japan|publisher=0verflow|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080731070845/http://www.0verflow.com/html/topics/060628_apology.html |archivedate=2008-07-31}} loads of patches,{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/html/topic/060628_patchinst.html|title=Summer Days patches|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, Japan|publisher=0verflow|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061104073011/http://www.0verflow.com/html/topic/060628_patchinst.html|archivedate= 2006-11-04}} and recall.{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/html/topic/060707_recovery.html|title=Apology and notice of recall for Limited Edition Summer Days|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, Japan|publisher=0verflow|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060714031603/http://www.0verflow.com/html/topic/060707_recovery.html|archivedate= 2006-07-14}} Another spin-off titled ''[[Cross Days]]'' was released on March 19, 2010. Set in the same continuity as ''School Days'', ''Cross Days'' follows the life of another protagonist, Yuuki Ashikaga, a high school freshman who also finds himself caught between the affection of two girls, Roka Kitsuregawa and Kotonoha Katsura, during his second term at Sakakino Academy. The game also features [[yaoi]] scenarios, during which Yuuki [[Cross-dressing|cross-dresses]] as a maid.{{cite web|url=http://crossdays.0verflow.com/story.html|title=Cross Days: Story|publisher=0verflow|location= Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, Japan|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese}} 0verflow released ''Shiny Days'' on February 2, 2012 which establishes a solid link between the ''Days'' series and ''Radish Vacation'' series.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} A third spin-off, ''[[Island Days]]'', was developed for the [[Nintendo 3DS]] and was released in Japan on July 3, 2014. The game, developed by Klon, focuses on Makoto and the girls becoming trapped on a remote island and includes [[tower defense]] elements.{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2014/01/10/island-days-coming-nintendo-3ds-may/|title=Island Days Is Coming To Nintendo 3DS In May|publisher=Siliconera|date=January 10, 2014|accessdate=January 10, 2014}} ===Manga=== Based on the story of the original game, ''School Days'' was reimagined as a [[manga]], illustrated by Homare Sakazuki and serialized in the [[Kadokawa Shoten]] magazine ''[[Comp Ace]]'' from May 26, 2006{{cite web|url=http://www.comptiq.com/release/ace/2006_07.html|title=''Comp Ace'' June 2006 Volume 7|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese}} to September 26, 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.comptiq.com/ace/index.php?%CB%DC%BB%EF%2F2007%C7%AF%2FVOL.19|title=''Comp Ace'' November 2007 Volume 19|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Cy3aUM5I?url=http://www.comptiq.com/ace/index.php?%CB%DC%BB%EF%2F2007%C7%AF%2FVOL.19|archivedate=2012-12-17|df=}} On July 12, 2007,{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/html/topics/index.html|title=School Days Comic Volume １ Release Announcement|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-09|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070720081356/http://www.0verflow.com/html/topics/index.html|archivedate=2007-07-20}} 0verflow announced that the manga had been collected into its first volume, comprising five chapters set to be released on July 26.{{cite web|url=http://www.kadokawa.co.jp/comic/bk_detail.php?pcd=200704000118|title=School Days (1)|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=2012-01-13}} Later that year, the second and final volume, comprising the remaining seven chapters, was released on November 26.{{cite web|url=http://www.kadokawa.co.jp/comic/bk_detail.php?pcd=200704000119|title=School Days (2)|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=2012-01-03}} {{Graphic novel list/header | OneLanguage = yes | Width = }} {{Graphic novel list | VolumeNumber = 1 | RelDate = July 26, 2007 | ISBN = 978-4-04-713946-6 | ChapterListCol1 = {{Numbered list|start=1 |{{Nihongo|"Confession"|告白|"Kokuhaku"|extra2= ～boys & girls～}} |{{Nihongo|"The Couple's Distance"|二人の距離|"Futari no Kyori"|extra2= ～distance～}} |{{Nihongo|"First Kiss"|ファーストキッス|"Fāsuto Kissu"|extra2= ～step for skip～}} }} | ChapterListCol2 = {{Numbered list|start=4 |{{Nihongo|"Another Good Luck Charm"|もうひとつのおまじない|"Mō Hitotsu no Omajinai"|extra2= ～wish & pain～}} |{{Nihongo|"And the Story Begins"|そして始まる物語|"Soshite Hajimaru Monogatari"|extra2= ～decide～}} }} | Summary = }} {{Graphic novel list | VolumeNumber = 2 | RelDate = November 26, 2007 | ISBN = 978-4-04-713965-7 | ChapterListCol1 = {{Numbered list|start=6 |{{Nihongo|"Right and Left Hand"|右手と左手|"Migite to Hidarite"|extra2= ～unbalance～}} |{{Nihongo|"Warmth"|ぬくもり|"Nukumori"|extra2= ～sign～}} |{{Nihongo|"The Couple's Feelings"|二人の想い|"Futari no Omoi"|extra2= ～ripple mind～}} |{{Nihongo|"Mask"|仮面|"Kamen"|extra2= ～innocent～}} }} | ChapterListCol2 = {{Numbered list|start=10 |{{Nihongo|"Two People and One Person"|フタリとヒトリ|"Futari to Hitori"|extra2= ～fall down～}} |{{Nihongo|"Slanted Words"|歪むコトバ|"Hizumu Kotoba"|extra2= ～period～}} |{{Nihongo|"The Couple's World"|二人のセカイ|"Futari no Sekai"|extra2= ～world's end～}} }} | Summary = }} {{Graphic novel list/footer}} Various artists also produced short manga of ''School Days'' that were compiled into two [[Comic anthology|comic anthologies]]. The "School Days Comic Anthology" was released by [[Ohzora Publishing]] on October 25, 2005 under their P-mate Comics [[imprint (trade name)|imprint]], containing nine short manga by individual artists.{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/web/goods_comic|title=0verflow: Books and Comics|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-10|language=Japanese}} On February 25, 2008, [[Ichijinsha]] printed the "School Days Kotonoha Anthology" under their DNA Media Comics imprint, a collection of manga primarily featuring the character Kotonoha Katsura.{{cite web|url=http://data.ichijinsha.co.jp/book/booksearch/booksearch_detail.php?i=75800428&TITLE=School+Days&WRITER=&ISBN=&CATEGORY=&SALEY=&SALEM=&WORD=&TYPE=like|title=School Days Kotonoha Anthology|publisher=[[Ichijinsha]]|accessdate=2012-01-11|language=Japanese}} ===Books and publications=== In addition to the manga, ''School Days'' was adapted into other print media. The first of these was the "School Days Visual Guide Book" published by [[Jive (publisher)|Jive]] on September 16, 2005,{{cite web|url= http://www.jive-ltd.co.jp/catalog/4861762227.html|title=Jive: School Days Visual Guidebook|location=Shinjuku, Tokyo|publisher=[[Jive (publisher)|Jive]]|accessdate=2012-01-10|language=Japanese}} an [[artbook]] of character illustrations, [[model sheet]]s, [[screenplay]], [[storyboard]]s and a [[visual hierarchy]] of the choices and corresponding scenes in the game.{{cite web|url=http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scdvisualguidebook.html|title=School Days Visual Guide Book|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[0verflow]]|date=2007-09-19|accessdate=2012-01-10|language=Japanese}} Separate editions for the anime television series and Playstation 2 game were also published, on December 1, 2007{{cite web|url=http://www.jive-ltd.co.jp/catalog/4861764622.html|title=Jive: School Days -TV Anime- Visual Guide Book|location=Shinjuku, Tokyo|publisher=[[Jive (publisher)|Jive]]|accessdate=2012-01-11|language=Japanese}} and March 21, 2008, respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.jive-ltd.co.jp/catalog/4861765049.html|title=Jive: School Days L×H Visual Guide Book|location=Shinjuku, Tokyo|publisher=[[Jive (publisher)|Jive]]|accessdate=2012-01-11|language=Japanese}} Collections of production work from the Windows game such as character and environment art, screenplay, artist commentaries and all manufactured promotional items were collected in the {{nihongo|"School Days Official Visual Art Works"|School Days 公式ビジュアル・アートワークス|School Days Koushiki Bijuaru Atowa Kusu}} on December 16, 2005{{cite web|url=http://www.jive-ltd.co.jp/catalog/4861762634.html|title=Jive: School Official Days Visual Art Works|location=Shinjuku, Tokyo|publisher=[[Jive (publisher)|Jive]]|accessdate=2012-01-11|language=Japanese}} and also featured in the "SummerDays {{sic}} & School Days Visual Collection" on August 31, 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.jive-ltd.co.jp/catalog/4861763304.html|title=Jive: SummerDays & School Days Visual Collection|location=Shinjuku, Tokyo|publisher=[[Jive (publisher)|Jive]]|accessdate=2012-01-11|language=Japanese}} The first of four [[light novel]]s, all illustrated by Junji Goto, was written by Ryuna Okada and printed by Harvest Publishing under their Harvest Novels imprint.{{cite web|url=http://www.harvest-inc.jp/label_harvest/kikan.html?2,14,0|title=Harvest Novels search: Overflow|publisher=Harvest Publishing|accessdate=2012-01-10|language=Japanese}} Released on December 1, 2005, {{nihongo|"School Days: Sekai Hen"|School Days 世界編}} retells the original story from the perspective of Sekai. Okada would follow up the book with {{nihongo|"School Days: Kotonoha Hen"|School Days 言葉編}} on January 1, 2006, switching to the perspective of Kotonoha. Two light novels were also published by Jive, the first of which was written by Takuya Baba, {{nihongo|"School Days: Kimi to Iru, Sora"|School Days 君といる、空}} and printed on December 16, 2005,{{cite web|url=http://www.jive-ltd.co.jp/catalog/4861762456.html|title=Jive: School Days: Kimi to Iru, Sora|location=Shinjuku, Tokyo|publisher=[[Jive (publisher)|Jive]]|accessdate=2012-01-11|language=Japanese}} and a second by Hiro Akiduki, "School Days: Innocent Blue", released on April 28.{{cite web|url=http://www.jive-ltd.co.jp/catalog/4861765056.html|title=Jive: -TV Anime- School Days Innocent Blue|location=Shinjuku, Tokyo|publisher=[[Jive (publisher)|Jive]]|accessdate=2012-01-11|language=Japanese}} ===Anime=== {{see also|List of School Days episodes}} ''School Days'' was adapted into a twelve-episode [[anime]] television series by [[TNK (company)|TNK]].{{cite web|url=http://www.e-tnk.net/anime/anime_top.html|title=TNK list of previous works|publisher=[[TNK (company)|TNK]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=2012-01-09}} Concrete news of this first appeared on June 1, 2007,{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/html/topics/index.html|title=Updates: June 1 ~ November 12, 2007|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[0verflow]]|date=2007-06-01|accessdate=2012-01-07|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080217125225/http://www.0verflow.com/html/topics/index.html|archivedate=2008-02-17 }} when 0verflow announced via its blog that the show's official website had gone live.{{cite web|url=http://0verflow.com/html/diary/2007/20070601_diary.html|title=TV animation news|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[0verflow]]|date=2007-06-01|accessdate=2012-01-07|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629192745/http://www.0verflow.com/html/diary/2007/20070601_diary.html|archivedate=2007-06-29 }} Stations participating in the broadcast included [[TV Kanagawa]], [[Chiba TV]], [[TV Aichi]], [[TV Osaka]], [[TV Saitama]] and [[AT-X (company)|AT-X]], the premiere of which would air on TV Kanagawa on July 3.{{cite web|url=http://www.schooldays-anime.com/index.html|title=School Days anime homepage|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-10|language=Japanese|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090318190728/http://www.schooldays-anime.com/index.html|archivedate=2009-03-18}} The anime was aired until September 27 and finished its broadcast on AT-X.{{cite web|url=http://www.schooldays-anime.com/news/index.html|title=School Days TV anime broadcasting in July 2007!!|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-10|language=Japanese|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090227023432/http://www.schooldays-anime.com/news/index.html|archivedate=2009-02-27 }} From September 26, 2007 to February 27, 2008, the series was compiled into six limited and regular edition [[DVD]]s.{{cite web|url=http://0verflow.com/html/topics/070626_schooldays_dvd.html|title=School Days TV Anime DVD Information|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-10|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080222185102/http://0verflow.com/html/topics/070626_schooldays_dvd.html|archivedate=2008-02-22}} TNK also produced two [[direct-to-video]] ([[OVA]]) episodes of ''School Days''. The first, titled "Valentine Days", was bundled with limited edition copies of ''School Days L×H'', and features an unrelated comedic romp through [[Valentine's Day]] as Kotonoha, Sekai, and Otome try to give Makoto [[giri choco]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.interchannel.jp/game/SDLH/gaiyou_tokuten1.html|title=PlayStation 2 "School Days L × H" Limited Edition: Bonus Bundle|publisher=[[Interchannel]]|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080110230851/http://www.interchannel.jp/game/SDLH/gaiyou_tokuten1.html|archivedate=2008-01-10}} The second, "Magical Heart Kokoro-chan", jaunts the series into [[magical girl]] territory, portraying Kokoro Katsura as the superheroine Magical Heart; it was released on March 26, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/html/topics/080121_magical_cocolo.html|title=School Days OVA Special: Magical Heart Kokoro-chan|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123073327/http://www.0verflow.com/html/topics/080121_magical_cocolo.html|archivedate=2008-01-23}} [[Discotek Media]] has acquired the television series and the "Magical Heart Kokoro-chan" OVA to be released on DVD on June 24, 2014 with English subtitles.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-02-26/discotek-licenses-school-days-magical-heart-kokoro-chan|title=Discotek Licenses School Days, Magical Heart Kokoro-chan|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=February 26, 2014|accessdate=February 27, 2014}} ====Delay of finale==== [[File:Schooldaysniceboat.jpg|right|thumb|Screenshot of the [[MS Skagastøl]] as it appeared in the original compilation footage. The "Nice boat." comment and subsequent meme would derive from this.]] On September 17, 2007, the day before the twelfth and final episode of the televised anime was to air on TV Kanagawa, a sixteen-year-old girl murdered her forty-five-year-old father in their [[Kyoto]] home with an axe. TV Kanagawa promptly cancelled the Tuesday airing of the finale for its similarly violent content, replacing it instead with a thirty-minute video compilation of scenery footage from [[Norway]], played to [[August Wilhelmj]]'s "[[Air on the G String]]". Newspapers such as ''[[The Japan Times]]'' and ''[[Mainichi Shimbun]]'' reported on the killing and episode preempt on September 19.{{cite web|url=http://mainichi.jp/enta/mantan/anime/archive/news/2007/09/20070919mog00m200002000c.html|title=Schoolgirl murders father, defers final broadcast of School Days|publisher=[[Mainichi Shimbun]]|accessdate=2012-01-10|language=Japanese|date=2007-09-19|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071015145502/http://mainichi.jp/enta/mantan/anime/archive/news/2007/09/20070919mog00m200002000c.html|archivedate=2007-10-15}}{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20070919a6.html|title=Teenage girl admits killing dad with ax|publisher=[[The Japan Times]]|accessdate=2012-01-10|date=2007-09-19}} According to ''Mainichi Shimbun'', Chiba TV and TV Aichi had also cancelled their airings, with AT-X the only station remaining indecisive. 0verflow issued an apology through their blog the same day, asking viewers to stay tuned for updates.{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/html/topics/070919_schooldays_12.html|title=About the School Days episode 12 broadcast|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[0verflow]]|date=2007-09-19|accessdate=2012-01-10|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080217130238/http://www.0verflow.com/html/topics/070919_schooldays_12.html|archivedate=2008-02-17 }} In the following week, 0verflow announced that it had arranged for two screenings of the edited finale at the [[Tokyo Anime Center|Akihabara 3D Theater]] on September 27. Those wishing to attend would be required to register a seat by email, be at least 18 years old with photo ID, and bring a Windows copy of ''School Days'' or ''Summer Days''.{{cite web|url=http://12.0verflow.com/|title=School Days TV anime sign-up|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-13|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014001708/http://12.0verflow.com/|archivedate=2007-10-14}} That same day AT-X announced that it had decided to air the unedited finale on September 27 and October 1.{{cite web|url=http://www.at-x.com/whats_new/detail.html/1291|title=School Days episode 12 broadcast information|publisher=[[AT-X (company)|AT-X]]|date=2007-09-26|language=Japanese|accessdate=2012-01-13}} In the wake of the broadcast change, a screen capture of the [[Norway|Norwegian]] M/S Skagastøl{{cite web|url=http://www.fjord1.no/en/default.asp?page=1556&pagesub=0|title=Fjord1: Vessels|publisher=[[Fjord1 Fylkesbaatane]]|location=[[Florø]], [[Norway]]|accessdate=2012-01-10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120526082137/http://www.fjord1.no/en/default.asp?page=1556|archivedate=2012-05-26|df=}} from the slideshow surfaced on the Internet alongside the caption "Nice boat.", a phrase which gained popularity in Japan.{{cite web|url=http://www.new-akiba.com/archives/2007/09/nice_boat.html|title="Nice boat." meme born from discontinued broadcast of School Days anime|publisher=new-akiba.com|location=Akihabara, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-05-07|language=Japanese}} [[Google Trends]] recorded a spike in "Nice Boat" searches around the third-quarter of 2007{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/trends/?q=nice+boat|title=Google Trends: Nice boat.|publisher=[[Google]]|location=Mountain View, California|accessdate=2012-01-10}} while ''[[Yomiuri Shinbun]]'', a Japanese newspaper, reported that "Nice boat" was the tenth most popular [[Yahoo! Japan]] search from September 17 to September 23.{{cite news|last=Fukuda|first=Jun|title=Henken Jochōsuru Kajō Hannō Unzari |script-title=ja:偏見助長する過剰反応うんざり |trans-title=Fed Up With the Encouraging Overreaction Bias|publisher=[[Yomiuri Shinbun]]|date=2007-09-26}} ''Nice Boat'' had become so well known that it was used in other media. The meme appeared as an [[Easter egg (media)|Easter egg]] in the first episode of ''[[List of Ef episodes#Ef: A Tale of Memories.|Ef: A Tale of Memories.]]'',{{Cite episode|title=Eve|episodelink=List of Ef episodes|series=Ef: A Tale of Memories.|serieslink=Ef: A Fairy Tale of the Two.|credits=|network=[[Chiba Television Broadcasting]]|station=CTC|airdate=2007-10-07|season=|seriesno=|number=1|minutes=7:06|language=Japanese}} and was parodied on February 13, 2009 when the [[Kadokawa Pictures]] [[YouTube]] channel uploaded a short [[Montage (filmmaking)|montage]] of sailboats instead of the previously scheduled premiere of ''[[The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.japanator.com/that-s-it-i-give-up-first-episode-of-haruhi-chan-not-finished-viewers-get-half-decent-boat-instead-9306.phtml|title=That's it, I give up: First episode of Haruhi-chan not finished, viewers get half-decent boat instead|publisher=Japanator|date=2009-02-13|author=Brad Rice|accessdate=2012-01-13}} 0verflow capitalized on the popularity of the phrase, naming their booth at Comiket 73 "Nice boat." and selling meme-inspired merchandise.{{cite web|url=http://niceboat.0verflow.com/|title=0verflow: Comiket Market 73 information|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-10|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224183710/http://niceboat.0verflow.com/|archivedate=2007-12-24}} TNK also paid homage to the meme in "Magical Heart Kokoro-chan", a special direct-to-video episode of the animated series.{{Cite episode|title=School Days: Magical Heart Kokoro-chan|episodelink=List of School Days episodes|series=School Days|serieslink=|credits=|airdate=2007-10-07|season=|seriesno=|number=1|minutes=23:00|language=Japanese}} ===Concert film=== Besides the video releases of the ''School Days'' anime, a [[concert film]], the ''School Days Secret Live DVD'', was also produced by HOBiRECORDS.{{cite web|url=http://www.hobirecords.com/shohin_info/?hbr_scldvd|title=HOBiRECORDS: School Days Secret Live DVD|publisher=HOBiRECORDS|accessdate=2012-04-13|language=Japanese}} Released on June 26, 2006 in conjunction with ''Summer Days'',{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/html/topic/060617_goto_event.html|title=Junji Goto autograph session commemorating release of Summer Days|publisher=[[0verflow]]|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-04-13|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060626164323/http://www.0verflow.com/html/topic/060617_goto_event.html|archivedate=2006-06-26}} the film contains footage of a concert held on June 15, 2005{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/web/goods_dvd|title=0verflow: DVDs|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-04-13|language=Japanese}} featuring the performances of [[Miyuki Hashimoto]], [[YURIA]], [[CooRie|rino]], [[yozuca*]] and [[Minami Kuribayashi]]. ===Audio CDs=== From 2005 to 2010, [[Lantis (company)|Lantis]] published six albums of ''School Days'' music. The "School Days Vocal Album", a [[Compilation album|compilation]] featuring all nine of the game's closing themes, as performed by artists yozuca*, Miyuki Hashimoto, YURIA, [[Halko Momoi]], [[Minami Kuribayashi]], rino, and [[Kanako Ito]]{{cite web|url=http://www.lantis.jp/new-release/data.php?id=53ce03375ed26d0b57897d58235fc51b |title=Lantis: School Days Vocal Album|publisher=[[Lantis (company)|Lantis]]|location=Shibuya, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-11|language=Japanese}} was the first to be distributed, sharing its April 28, 2005 date with the release of the game itself. The remaining twenty-eight background scores, composed by KIRIKO/HIKO Sound, were released on July 21, officially completing the game's soundtrack.{{cite web|url=http://www.lantis.jp/new-release/data.php?id=315428a0a07e3002ddfae77efb62d4fc|title=Lantis: School Days Original Sound Track|publisher=[[Lantis (company)|Lantis]]|location=Shibuya, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-11|language=Japanese}} Another compilation, the "School Days Vocal Complete Album{{sic}}" featuring songs from ''Summer Days'' and ''Cross Days'', was released on October 8, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.lantis.jp/new-release/data.php?id=97ac26d616c1d6f8d36ea29ee26fe4f8|title=Lantis: School Days Vocal Complete Album|publisher=[[Lantis (company)|Lantis]]|location=Shibuya, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-12|language=Japanese}} Three weeks after the premiere of the televised anime on July 25, 2007, Lantis published the [[Single (music)|single]] "Innocent Blue" by DeviceHigh, a four-track disc featuring the anime opening of the same name, a disco-inspired song called Dancin' Joker, and their [[instrumental]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.lantis.jp/new-release/data.php?id=39dc67f121b6a4c1fd2e0860c86b4423 |title=Lantis: Innocent Blue by DeviceHigh|publisher=[[Lantis (company)|Lantis]]|location=Shibuya, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-12|language=Japanese}} Lantis followed with "School Days: Ending Theme+" on August 22, a sixteen-track disc containing all of the show's closing themes and background scores on September 26.{{cite web|url=http://www.lantis.jp/new-release/data.php?id=3319273b1fd6e85c758c5d95c1d9e5d1 |title=Lantis: School Days TV Original Sound Track|publisher=[[Lantis (company)|Lantis]]|location= Shibuya, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-12|language=Japanese}} In addition to music albums, six [[audio drama]]s were also produced. "School Days Little Promise", a chronicle of Sekai and Setsuna's childhoods, was the first. Featuring music by KIRIKO/HIKO Sound and Kanako Ito, HOBiRECORDS published "Little Promise" as a two-disc set, which 0verflow scheduled for release January 27, 2006.{{cite web|url=http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scddoramacd.html|title=School Days Little Promise: January 27, 2006 release|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-12|language=Japanese|date=2007-09-19|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051211114735/http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scddoramacd.html|archivedate=2005-12-11}} Pre-releases were sold at Comiket 69 from December 29 to 30, 2005.{{cite web|url=http://schooldays.0verflow.com/html/scdevent.html|title=Event information: Comiket 69|publisher=[[0verflow]]|location= Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, Japan|accessdate=2012-01-12|language=Japanese}} Sometime afterward however, 0verflow announced that pre-released copies of Little Promise were defective, and asked customers to mail in their discs for replacements. The release was also postponed to February 24.{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/html/top.html|title=School Days Little Promise: February 24 date change|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-12|language=Japanese|date=2007-09-19|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060212012259/http://www.0verflow.com/html/top.html|archivedate=2006-02-12}} Lantis released the remaining five dramas. "School Days Drama CD Vol. 1 Himitsu Hanazono" (ヒ・ミ・ツの花園), a merrymaking of the series six main girls, was released on August 8, 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.lantis.jp/new-release/data.php?id=fc57ae479be35a9e59ad7f8dea021f00|title=Lantis: School Days Drama CD Vol. 1|publisher=[[Lantis (company)|Lantis]]|location=Shibuya, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-12|language=Japanese}} A second, "School Days Drama CD Vol 2. Koi no Nou-hau" (恋のノ・ウ・ハ・ウ), was released October 24, 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.lantis.jp/new-release/data.php?id=b83eafd19f9690156797ed09f06c0fef|title=Lantis: School Days Drama CD Vol. 2|publisher=[[Lantis (company)|Lantis]]|location=Shibuya, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-12|language=Japanese}} Radio School Days was compiled into three separate albums: {{nihongo|"Futakumidake no Taiikusai"|二組だけの体育祭}} was released on November 21, 2007,{{cite web|url=http://www.lantis.jp/new-release/data.php?id=fd0155735dd89a063923dd131eea92ea|title=Lantis: Radio School Days Volume 1: Futakumidake no Taiikusai|publisher=[[Lantis (company)|Lantis]]|location= Shibuya, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-12|language=Japanese}} {{nihongo|"Futakumidake no Shakaika Kengaku"|二組だけの社会科見学}} on February 6, 2008,{{cite web|url=http://www.lantis.jp/new-release/data.php?id=540e45156f9f46d365f45cea711d085d|title=Lantis: Radio School Days Volume 2: Futakumidake no Shakaika Kengaku|publisher=[[Lantis (company)|Lantis]]|location= Shibuya, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-12|language=Japanese}} and {{nihongo|"Futakumi Ijou no Rakkasan Butai"|二組以上の落下傘部隊}} on June 21.{{cite web|url=http://www.lantis.jp/new-release/data.php?id=cba95d517d6e0adafbf76ad7528940b0|title=Lantis: Radio School Days Volume 3: Futakumi Ijou no Rakkasan Butai|publisher=[[Lantis (company)|Lantis]]|location= Shibuya, Tokyo|accessdate=2012-01-12|language=Japanese}} ===Merchandise=== Considerable effort was made to market and promote ''School Days'' before and after its release, including the sale of brand merchandise and use of incentives. Through public venues and through the company's online store, 0verflow sold brand keystraps, mousepads, phonecards, book covers, mugs, t-shirts,{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/web/goods_goods2|title=0verflow: Goods (2)|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-12|language=Japanese}} [[dakimakura]] cases, [[Polyvinyl chloride|PVC]] figures,{{cite web|url=http://www.0verflow.com/web/goods_goods|title=0verflow: Goods (1)|location=Kanda, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo|publisher=[[0verflow]]|accessdate=2012-01-12|language=Japanese}} [[lanyard]]s, business card holders and [[cosplay]] material such as the girls' school uniforms and plastic [[dōzuki]].{{cite book|title=School Days Official Visual Art Works|year=2005 |publisher=[[Jive (company)|Jive]]|isbn=978-4-86176-263-5|page=95}} ==Reception== ''UK Anime Network'', a British online anime and manga magazine, gave the television series a 7 out of 10, summarizing it as "An utter subversion of the high school romance genre, which is disturbing and unsettling... yet oddly compelling in its own way."{{Cite web |author=Hanley, Andy |url=http://www.uk-anime.net/anime/School_Days.html |title=Anime Review: School Days |work=UK Anime Network |date=June 8, 2009 |accessdate=August 26, 2016 }} ''THEM Anime Reviews'', a website devoted to the review of anime, gave the series a less favorable 1 out of 5 stars, citing "overblown, shallow, and flat" characters and that although "''School Days'' looks fascinating when you see screenshots of it and read episode guides", the reviewer found it to be "annoying, stupid, mean-spirited, and full of some of the biggest idiots [he had] seen in an anime in a long time."{{Cite web |author=Jones, Tim |url=http://www.themanime.org/viewreview.php?id=1185 |title=School Days |work=THEM Anime Reviews |date=March 25, 2010 |accessdate=August 26, 2016 }} On June 12, 2015, the [[Ministry of Culture (China)|Chinese Ministry of Culture]] listed ''School Days'' among 38 anime and manga titles banned in [[China]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2015/06/12/china-bans-38-japanese-anime-manga-titles-including-attack-titan |title=China bans 38 anime & manga titles incuding ''Attack on Titan'' |publisher=[[Special Broadcasting Service]] |date=2015-06-12 |accessdate=2018-08-31}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{Cite web|author=Martin, Theron|url=//www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/school-days/sub.dvd-complete-collection/.76385|title=School Days Sub.DVD - Complete Collection|work=Anime News Network|date=July 13, 2014}} * {{Cite web|author=Beveridge, Chris|url=http://www.fandompost.com/2012/05/09/school-days-complete-series-anime-review/|title=School Days Complete Series Anime Review|work=The Fandom Post|date=May 9, 2012}} ==External links== {{Portalbar|Anime and manga|2000s}} *[http://schooldays.us/ ''School Days HQ'' English website] *[http://schooldayshq.0verflow.com/ ''School Days HQ'' visual novel] at [[0verflow]] {{ja icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100208202055/http://www.sekaiproject.net/ ''Sekai Project''] *{{ann|anime|7815|School Days}} *{{vndb|14|title=School Days}} {{School Days|state=expanded}} games]] [[Category:Bishōjo games]] [[Category:Days series]] [[Category:DVD interactive technology]] [[Category:Eroge]] [[Category:Harem anime and manga]] [[Category:Lantis (company)]] revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
'''Shanto''' is a form of [[music of Guyana|Guyanese music]], related to both [[Calypso music|calypso]] and [[mento]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.research.wayne.edu/hum/brown_bag/03-04abstracts/Bernard%20Flyer.pdf|accessdate=October 1, 2006|title=The African Folk Music Tradition from Guyana: A Discourse and Performance|work=Brown Bag Colloquium Series 2003-2004|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060828102016/http://www.research.wayne.edu/hum/brown_bag/03-04abstracts/Bernard%20Flyer.pdf|archivedate=August 28, 2006|df=}}</ref> It became a major part of early popular music through its use in Guyanese [[vaudeville]] shows; songs are topical and light-hearted, often accompanied by a [[guitar]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gems-av.com/themakingofpopguyanesemusic.htm|title=The Making of Popular Guyanese Music|accessdate=October 1, 2006|author=Seals, Ray}}</ref>
== References and notes == <references/>
Shanto is a Bangla word meaning 'calm' derived from Sanskrit 'shant.'
[[Category:Calypso]] [[Category:Guyanese music]]
{{music-genre-stub}}

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Observances set by the Tamil calendar to [[:Category:Festivals in Tamil Nadu]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 20]].
revision.text:
{{Use Indian English|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} [[File:Murugar Statue.JPG|thumbnail|Lord Murugan(kartikeya)]] {{Kaumaram}} '''Sooranporu''' or '''Soorasamharam''' part of '''Skanda Sashti Vratham''' festival is a ritual folk performance that recreates the killing of [[Asuras]] by [[Lord Murugan]].<ref name="thehindu"/> It is performed in [[Tamil Nadu]], [[Sri Lanka]] and the [[Palakkad district|district of Palakkad]] in [[Kerala]] at temples dedicated to Murugan. The ''Soorasamharam'' festival is also celebrated in Thiruvannur Subramanya Swami temple in [[Kozhikode District]] kerala for more than a century in the name ''' Sooranpada'''.<ref name="thehindu">{{cite news|title=The fall of demons|url=http://www.thehindu.com/arts/theatre/the-fall-of-demons/article4244670.ece|accessdate=24 January 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|date=27 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Devotees throng Palani for Soorasamharam|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/devotees-throng-palani-for-soorasamharam/article881272.ece|accessdate=24 January 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|date=12 November 2010}}</ref> The 2016 date is November 5.<ref>http://tiruchendur.org/2016.kandasashti.htm</ref>
The Sooranporu performance is based on the story of Murugan, also known as [[Murugan|Skanda]], as given in the [[Skanda Purana|Skandapurana]]. In the days preceding the performance the Skandapaurana is narrated in the temple. The performance ends with the killing of Soorapadman (or Padmasura) and his race which is depicted through the symbolic beheading of the four Asuras Anamughan, Panumughan, Simhamughan and Soorapadman.<ref name="thehindu" /> The Asuras are beheaded by Murugan using his weapon the ''vel'' a kind of spear or javelin. For the performance the ''vel'' is specially consecrated and during the staging of the show it is ceremonially placed on the neck of the effigy after which the head is removed, depicting the beheading of the Asura.<ref name="thehindu" /><ref name="thehindu_a">{{cite news|title=Thousands of devotees witness 'Soorasamharam'|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/thousands-of-devotees-witness-soorasamharam/article4110361.ece|accessdate=24 January 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|date=19 November 2012}}</ref> Sooranporu is staged at the end of a week-long ''Kanda Sashti'' festival.<ref name="thehindu_a" /><ref>{{cite news|title='Soorasamharam' performed|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/soorasamharam-performed/article3067049.ece|accessdate=24 January 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|date=28 October 2006}}</ref>
Sooranporu is preceded by several ceremonies on the last day of the ''Kanda Sashti'' festival. Special [[Puja (Hinduism)|pujas]] are conducted and the deity of Murugan is ritually anointed ([[abhishekam]]) and devotees seek the deity's darshan. In some parts of Tamil Nadu women devotees observe a six-day fast which they break at the end of the Sooranporu. In [[Palani]], a procession of Lord Murugan (known here as ''Dandayuthapaniswamy'') is taken down from the [[Palani Murugan temple|hill temple]] and led through the main thoroughfares of the town before the Sooranporu.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tamilnadu.com/temples/dhandapani-murugan-kovil.html|title=Dhandapani Murugan Kovil|publisher=Tamilnadu.com|date=5 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130307142728/http://tamilnadu.com/temples/dhandapani-murugan-kovil.html|archivedate=7 March 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Thousands witness 'Soorasamharam'|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/thousands-witness-soorasamharam/article881500.ece|accessdate=24 January 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|date=12 November 2010}}</ref>
In Tamil Nadu, Sooranporu is witnessed every year by large crowds of devotees and the [[Government of Tamil Nadu|state government]] and [[Indian Railways]] ply special buses and trains to facilitate their travel.<ref>{{cite news|title=Thousands of devotees witness Soorasamharam|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/thousands-of-devotees-witness-soorasamharam/article4110166.ece|accessdate=24 January 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|date=19 November 2012}}</ref> In Kerala's Palakkad district, Sooranporu is held in all the major Tamil settlements in the district.<ref name="thehindu" />

{{more references|date=May 2018}} '''Television in Spain''' was launched in October 1956, when the state broadcaster [[Televisión Española]] (TVE) started regular broadcasts. The first private channels started in 1990. Colour transmissions started in 1972 after two years of test transmissions, with all programming transmitted in color from 1977, and colour commercials, which started in 1978. Currently, television is one of the leading mass media of the country, and by 2008 was in 99.7% of households in Spain according to INE statistics. Until recently terrestrial television was considered an essential public service. Broadcasting is managed both directly by the State and indirectly, through controlled concessions to private firms. The Audiovisual Law of 2010 changed this by defining radio and television as commercial services that individuals pay for, fostering liberalization within some constraints. ==Analogue terrestrial television== Analogue terrestrial television in Spain began on 28 October 1956. Televisión Española (now [[La 1 (Spain)|La 1]]) was the very first regular television channel, and operated alone until 1966, when a second channel (now [[La 2 (Spain)|La 2]]) was launched. La 1 and La 2 were the only authorized television channels in Spain until 1982, when [[Euskal Telebista]] was launched in the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]] and, in the following year, [[TV3 (Catalonia)|TV3]] in [[Catalonia]], thus ending TVE's monopoly. More channels were launched in the 1980s, each broadcasting to their respective [[Autonomous communities of Spain|autonomous communities]]: [[Canal Nou|Canal 9]], [[Canal Sur]], [[Telemadrid]], and [[Televisión de Galicia]] (TVG), prior to the full liberalization of television with the law of 1989 which permitted the establishment of private commercial channels. [[Antena 3 (Spain)|Antena 3]], [[Telecinco]] and [[Canal+ Spain|Canal+]] were launched in 1990, in January, March and September respectively, finishing the public television monopoly in Spain. Through the 1990s and 2000s (decade), more autonomic channels (most of them public, but some of them private) were launched, and all of them created [[FORTA]], a union of public autonomic channels. Many local channels were also launched, some of them created the [[Localia]] Network. During the 1990s, dozens of local channels started broadcasting without a license. The government declared that channels that proved to be operating for a long time could go on working, but blocked new unlicensed channels. In the 2000s (decade), the analog national and autonomic channels started [[simulcast]] on digital terrestrial television. In 2005, Canal+ stopped its analog service to move to [[Digital Plus]] and was substituted by [[Cuatro (TV channel)|Cuatro]]. Some weeks later, the last analog national private channel, [[La Sexta]], started testing broadcasts, to begin its regular analog schedule in 2006. In 2009, the analog service started its closure in a process that lasted one year. On 3 April 2010 the analog service was officially discontinued but there are still some small local analog channels operating, most of them the unlicensed analog channels. ==Digital terrestrial television== The development of digital terrestrial television was very similar to the failure of [[ITV Digital]] in the [[United Kingdom]]. Digital terrestrial television was introduced in the country by the pay per view platform [[Quiero Television]]. In May 2002, statewide operators were required to start broadcasting in [[DVB-T]]. Yet, Quiero TV ceased transmissions in 2002 after a commercial failure. Unlike the UK, the three and half multiplexes left by the platform were not reassigned to other operators, and so 5 channels were squashed into a single multiplex. On 30 November 2005, digital terrestrial television was relaunched as a free service with 20 channels and 14 radio stations, along with 23 regional- and local-language channels in their respective areas. Currently about 95% of the population can receive DTT. Each multiplex has a minimum of 4 SD channels each or one HD channel. [[Televisió de Catalunya]] and [[Aragón Televisión]] are using spare bandwidth in their own digital multiplex to broadcast test HD streams. ==Cable== Digital cable is slowly replacing the aging analogue service of the major cable provider [[ONO (Spain)|Ono]]. [[TeleCable (Spain)|Telecable]], a cable ISP operating in [[Asturias]] has begun trials for 1000 mega bytes per second service and is the first to broadcast HD channels. [[Mundo-R|R]], a cable operator in Galicia, has completely switched pay TV to digital (DVB-C) by 2008 but free channels are simulcast as analog services, so users without a set-top box can watch them (including most free-to-air channels available on digital terrestrial TV in each location). ==Satellite== Digital satellite services has existed since 1997 from [[SES Astra|Astra]] and Hispasat satellites. The [[Movistar+]] pay platform has carried some HDTV tests on [[Astra 19.2°E]] on 16 June 2005. This platform (before Canal+) has a lot of exclusives channels as "#0" by February 2016 without having to pay the licence of the brand Canal+.http://www.movistarplus.es/diales A high definition version of Canal+ 1 (Canal+ 1 HD) now is called "#0"; started on 29 January 2008, together with HD versions of Canal+ Deportes (now movistar Deportes) and Canal+ DCine (now movistar Dcine) broadcast from [[Astra 1KR]]. ==IPTV== During 2007 [[Telefónica]] ran trials of [[VDSL]] services up to 52 Mbit/s - However, the results were not as good as expected. For this reason, Telefónica will use [[FTTH]] for future IPTV services. Now Telefónica use Movistar+ in IPTV and Satellite. ==List of television stations== {{main|List of television stations in Spain}} ===Former analogue and digital=== Analogue service was discontinued in April 2010. Since then, all national and regional terrestrial channels are digital. * [[La 1 (Spain)|La 1]] ("La Uno"): Spain's principal [[public broadcasting|public-service]] television network, publicly owned and financed and offering programming aimed at a wide public. Previous names include La Primera Cadena and TVE-1. * [[La 2 (Spain)|La 2]] ("La Dos"): the country's second nationwide public channel, providing alternative programming to La 1. Previous names include UHF, La Segunda Cadena and TVE-2. * [[Antena 3 (Spain)|Antena 3]]: One of the nationwide private television networks that received a broadcasting licence in 1989. Antena 3 airs general programs such as news, movies, reality shows, sport events and quizzes. * [[Cuatro (TV channel)|Cuatro]]: replaced [[Canal+ Spain]] after the end of its terrestrial analogue broadcast on 7 November 2005. Cuatro, founded by [[Sogecable]], airs general programs such as news, movies, documentaries, reality shows, sport events and quizzes. In December 2009 it was acquired by [[Mediaset España Comunicación|Gestevisión Telecinco]] (currently Mediaset España).http://www.elpais.com/articulo/economia/Telecinco/crean/mayor/grupo/television/abierto/elpepieco/20091219elpepieco_2/Tes * [[Telecinco]]: one of the nationwide private television networks that received a broadcasting license in 1989. Telecinco airs general programs such as news, movies, reality shows, sport events and quizzes. * [[laSexta]]: the last nationwide private station, owned by the Mexican corporation [[Televisa]] and the Spanish production company [[Mediapro]], Mediapro was the real owner of the channel, Televisa had also a part of the stock. It started to broadcast in March 2006. It was born with some technical limits, since its analogue broadcast covered, at the most, 85% of the Spanish population. In 2012, it was acquired by [[Atresmedia|Grupo Antena 3]] (currently Atresmedia). * And most [[Autonomous communities of Spain|regions]] (''Comunidades Autónomas'') of Spain have their own public network service : [[Telemadrid]] in Madrid, [[Canal Extremadura Televisión]] in [[Extremadura]], [[7RM]] in [[Murcia]], [[Canal Sur]] and [[Canal 2 Andalucía]] in Andalusia, [[Castilla–La Mancha TV|CMT]] in [[Castilla–La Mancha]], [[Televisión de Galicia|TVG]] Televisión de Galicia, [[TV3 (Catalonia)|TV3]] in Catalonia, [[Canal Nou|Canal 9]] in Valencia, [[EITB]] Euskal Telebista in Basque Country, [[Radiotelevisión del Principado de Asturias|TPA]] in Asturias, [[TV Canaria]] in Canary Islands, etc. Most of these channels (called "las autonómicas") are integrated in the [[FORTA]] ("Federación de Organismos de Radio Televisión Autonómicos"). ===Digital TV channels=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !Corporation||Channel in Standard Definition||Channel in High Definition||Channel in 4K||Radio station||Mux |- valign="center" |[[RTVE|Radio Televisión Española]] |[[La 1 (Spanish TV channel)|La 1]]
